key_behaviors: Uses ChatGPT weekly for personal tasks
Inputs medical exam results into ChatGPT to interpret health condition
Uses ChatGPT to edit long personal letters for typos and style
Copies exercise names from ChatGPT and searches Google for pictures
Envisions an AI that could research and book professional training workshops
pain_points: ChatGPT cannot generate or display exercise pictures, requiring a second tool (Google)
Limited trust in AI outputs (moderate trust, needs verification)
Uncertainty about how AI would integrate with calendar, email, and other personal systems
No examples of tasks where AI fails, suggesting limited awareness of AI’s boundaries
trust_factors: Wants AI to be as efficient and effective as the user themselves
Needs AI to consistently understand needs and deliver accurate results before delegating tasks
Perceives human interviewers as more empathetic, which influences trust
desires: AI that can locate, evaluate, and book relevant training workshops automatically
Seamless integration with calendar, email, and other personal productivity tools
Ability to provide visual content (e.g., exercise images) within the same conversation
Higher reliability that would raise trust to a level‑5, allowing the user to rely on AI without double‑checking

verbatim_quotes.quote: I put the results of my exams into ChatGPT and asked it to tell me what the results indicated regarding my current health condition...
The other way I have used ChatGPT is when I'm writing long letters to my friends and family members. I ask ChatGPT to edit the letter for any typos or anything I might have missed.

When I use it for health information, I wanted to see the exercises that were suggested for my health condition, and ChatGPT didn't generate the pictures. So, I had to copy and paste the names of the exercises and then ask Google to find the pictures.
On average, how much do you trust the results or suggestions you get from AI tools? 3 - Moderate trust

I think a personal assistant would help me find training programs that I could use when I'm writing content or developing a point of view for my work. It could show me what workshops are available on the topic, help me select the top ones, and then assist me in booking them.
If the AI assistant is as efficient as I am, and not just efficient but also effective, and if the AI system is able to understand what I need and reach a level five, then I will be able to use it.
I don't know what the purpose will be. It might be to send emails for me and manage calendar invites, but I don't understand the purpose.
Just the fact that the humans understand me better, and it's more like a conversation than an interview or a survey.

verbatim_quotes.topic: Human empathy as a trust factor

unique_insights: The participant leverages AI to become a more proactive patient, using it to ask deeper questions during a medical appointment—a clear example of AI enhancing personal agency in health decisions. Additionally, they view AI as a "survey-like" tool lacking empathy, which directly impacts their willingness to trust and rely on it for more complex, personal tasks.
